GameEventAction.Description:
With our recent conquest of the colony {0} we can choose whether to implement 'The Scouring'.
Scouring this newly-acquired colony will grant us an [RESEARCH]extra tech[/RESEARCH] from this conquest.
Some of the [BAD]existing population will be consumed[/BAD], providing food to [BONUS]temporarily boost population growth for Gizureans throughout our empire[/BONUS].
Our diligent efforts to scour the planet will also no doubt [RESOURCE]reveal any hidden resource caches[/RESOURCE].
Scouring will also [WARN]lower colony happiness[/WARN] for two years and dramatically [WARN]reduce the development level[/WARN] of the colony.
It will also [WARN]harm our reputation[/WARN] with other factions.
Should we implement 'The Scouring' at our new colony {0}?

What is the Hive?
They seem familiar, not unlike ourselves in appearance, and yet unfathomably alien.
Even being in the same system with them is... disturbing. Our people report feeling uneasy, as though they are being watched, hearing muffled voices that cannot be understood. There are disturbing dreams, anxiety, inexplicable eruptions of terror.
What are these things? Why do we feel as though we should know the answer?

There has never been a better time to be Gizurean. Though that may not be true. It might have been better in the distant past. We cannot say with any certainty.
Still, it is a very good time. We are on cusp of traversing the great unknown, claiming all we find for ourselves. Our stories say that once we spread out among the stars, growing, expanding, multiplying. All fled from our relentless, unstoppable expansion. There were so many of us, and that made us the greatest and the strongest.
Still, the past haunts us. How did we end up reduced to living on a single planet, growing, always growing, and so finding ourselves short of space? What caused us to lose all we once had? Did someone take it from us? They must be made to give it back!
And were we once... more? Each of us feels connected to the whole of Gizurean-kind, but that connection seems... wrong. Diminished. Like muffled sounds heard through a wall. Where there should be voices, there is only silence.
The secret of our former nature may be out there, among the stars. And when we find that secret, we will know who to blame, and we will devour them.
Something strange is happening on this world. Inexplicable activity. We should learn more before we travel to the surface and consume everything of value.

There are things on this world. Living things that are not Gizurean. They are unfamiliar, but something about them suggests they might be delicious. We will have to report back.
They move to and fro making noises that resemble language, and yet no one from our world can understand them, so maybe not language after all. The creatures work strange devices, possibly machines, though we do not recognize them, so also possibly junk.
Before killing and eating these creatures, should we study them and their maybe-machines? Doing so will distract us from other important projects, such as growing stronger. It might be better simply to devour them.

The aliens were delicious, though the fur sticks in your mandibles.
We have ravaged the world for anything of value. We enjoyed doing it.

Ha ha! These creatures had intelligence. Of a sort. They did not seem to like it when we ate them.
We have discovered that we could take over the operation of their machines, which are now our machines. We own them! We have studied their research base and learned to operate it. We now know all the things they knew. Exploration is almost as enjoyable as consumption.
It is time to start looking for more aliens!
We are receiving a message from the aliens on Manabu. They speak our language! We will listen to what they have to say and weigh the merits of their words before we decide if we want to eat them.

"Greetings, travelers! We are Teekans, and we welcome you as partners in trade. We are glad you're here, because we need your help.
We established a research base in your home system so we could learn more about you in order to pave the way to a beneficial trading relationship. Unfortunately, we have lost contact with our researchers. Do you know anything about their circumstances?"

Their circumstances are they were delicious, but it may not be wise to mention this. We shall have to decide how to handle these creatures. Should we lie to them or intimidate them by boasting of our conquest?

We have sent the following message:
"Warm-blooded aliens, the reason you have not heard from your scientist is because we ate them, and devoured aliens do not have much to say. We took their flesh and we took their research station, and now they are ours. Maybe your world will be ours someday soon."
You ate our researchers

We've lied to the foolish mammals and said that a terrible disease afflicted their outpost.
We did our best to save them, but their disease was too stupid to respond to our excellent medicines. One of their babies died in our arms. It was very sad. There was much weeping on our homeworld.
To console ourselves, we claimed their research base and used it to further our own growth. Any rumors of us eating the aliens' corpses are highly exaggerated.

We are receiving another transmission from Manabu.
"Thank you for your report. We grieve for our lost scientists, but we appreciate your efforts to save them. We will have to work on our understanding of your language, because our translations make you sound a little irrational, but we believe that is our fault."
"As a demonstration of our goodwill, our scientists will share with you some of our recently acquired knowledge."
"You might wish to know that other travelers have reported sightings of aliens who resemble your species, but they are described as incapable of communication. They have been called mindless devourers. We wished to warn you, lest you run into them."

Mindless devourers? In what way do they resemble us? We are very thoughtful and deliberate devourers.
Even so, there is much we don't know about who we were before the Cataclysm. Creatures that resemble the Gizureans may provide an important link to our past, and that may help us to understand our true nature.

We are receiving another transmission from Manabu. These aliens are very chatty.
"There is one more thing we wish to discuss. Long ago, one of our research vessels discovered an alien in cryo-suspension. We did not recognize its species or know what to do with it, but we now see this being is a Gizurean. After encountering you, we awakened this sleeper, who is indeed a Gizurean from long ago. A scientist, in fact.
We are willing to return him to you for a very low cost. Just to cover our storage and resuscitation costs, you understand."
Slowly-expanding aliens, we do not need an old scientist. We can always breed new scientists. Modern scientists.
You declined our offer
A scientist from the past could be of great value. We've paid these shifty mammals their ransom. We are receiving more information from them now.
"We're sending you your scientist now. He is a bit... special. Let's call him special. But he is a very intelligent scientist, so good luck to you, friends. I hope we can do business again soon."

The scientist the aliens have handed over is irrational. He comes from long ago, from a time when Gizureans knew far more and were spread out across the galaxy. That knowledge should prove very useful, but there are some problems.
The scientist has difficulty talking about his time. He mostly rants about the lack of voices in his head. We wish he could communicate more clearly, but he only says "Words are insufficient and were once unnecessary."
No one likes working with this scientist. Even so, he is very clever.

Alarming news from Nazareno. This world is inhabited by a small population of Gizureans, but they are not like us. They are barely sentient, living animal-like lives with no ability to communicate. They do a great deal of reproducing, but they live in such poor conditions that many die, and their numbers do not increase.
We believe that these pathetic creatures were once admirable Gizureans like ourselves, but something went horribly wrong.
Do we eradicate these diminished Gizureans and take their desirable world for our own? Alternatively, we could study them, and possibly risk exposing ourselves to whatever caused them to devolve? Such a move would be expensive and likely cause unhappiness among our populace.

As there is only a small and localized population of degenerate Gizureans, it was quite simple to poison their water supply and watch them perish. They thrashed about. It was most amusing. And now their world is ours! They never had a chance. It does not pay to be stupid.

Our study of the degenerate Gizureans suggest that they have been afflicted with some kind of mind virus. No, don't worry. There is no chance of it spreading now. We have learned that it affects the psychic centers in their brains.
By dissecting many of these creatures, we've learned how they differ from us, and that has, in turn, taught us much about ourselves. Normal Gizureans maintain a low-level psychic contact with one another at all times. That's why we feel connected to one another. These animal-like Gizureans have absolutely no psychic connection with one another. It is this isolation that has made them like animals.
Our scientists, who are surely the best in the galaxy, believe that it is possible to focus our research on a means of reversing the blockage and turning these pathetic creatures into normal Gizureans. Or is that too much of a bother? We could just as easily ignore the creatures, crowd them out of their habitat, and allow them to enjoy a slow and natural extinction.
These primitive Gizureans are dispiriting to look at, but they will do no harm should we choose to colonize this world.

Our scientists have given a great deal of thought to the degenerate Gizureans on Nazareno, and they now believe they can cure them more easily than previously believed possible.
Perhaps a converted population will be of use to us. Or we can just leave the creatures alone.
There is no need to do anything about the mindless Gizureans. We have already forgotten they were there.

Our scientists have finished their work researching a cure for the mindless Gizureans. They are now no longer mindless and can be made useful members of our society. We shall put them to work at once.
Having an underclass of oppressed, menial workers will make us even stronger!

Our scientists have finished their work researching a cure for the mindless Gizureans. They are now no longer mindless and can be made useful members of our society. We shall put them to work at once.
Having an underclass of oppressed, menial workers will make us even stronger!

On the surface of {0} we've discovered the wreckage of an ancient Gizurean ship, likely dating back to before the Cataclysm. It is surely worth studying, though we could also salvage it for resources.

We have taken the ancient Gizurean ship apart. It has many useful components that will help us to grow, grow, grow.
No regrets!

Scientists have begun their study of the crashed Gizurean ship on {0}. At first we were quite pleased to learn about ancient Gizurean cleverness, but then things took a dark turn.
The scientists began sending shrill, discordant, nonsensical messages. Then they stopped responding to our efforts to communicate. That usually indicates something has gone wrong. We must now decide if we want to cut our losses or send another team.

We can replace those scientists, so no real loss.
Using drones, we've managed to dismantle the crashed ship for parts.
Our scientists appear to have gone insane and killed one another or themselves. We are pleased the ship no longer exists, and all Gizureans everywhere can breathe a sigh of relief that we have not unleashed some terrible evil upon the universe.
Gizureans are not quitters. We've sent another team of scientists. Better ones this time. We are confident nothing will go wrong.

Something went wrong.
We have discovered what happened to the original team investigating the ancient ship. They were exposed to a psychic plague. We were unable to contain the infected, who felt an irrepressible urge to return to our homeworld. We were unable to stop them.
There is now an outbreak on the homeworld, and the disease threatens to spread rapidly throughout our populations. We must take steps as soon as possible to find a cure.

These ARE better scientists. They've found the previous team dead, having murdered one another in an orgy of unhinged violence, but you have to expect that sort of thing can happen when exploring space.
We will focus on postivie things. By studying the ship, we have learned a great deal about ancient Gizurean technology.

Our scientists, who are really very smart, have discovered a cure for the psychic plague. We have learned some things about medicine and ancient Gizurean technology in the process.
The dead will soon be replaced, and so we have lost nothing.
On the surface of {0} we've discovered the wreckage of an ancient ship, likely dating back to before the Cataclysm. It is surely worth studying, though we could also salvage it for resources.

We have taken the ancient ship apart. It has many useful components that will help our efforts.
No regrets!

Scientists have begun their study of the crashed ship on {0}. They reported that they believed it to be of Gizurean design. Then things began to go very wrong.
The scientists began sending shrill, discordant, nonsensical messages. Then they stopped responding to our efforts to communicate. We must decide if we want to risk sending more scientists.

Using drones, we've managed to dismantle the crashed ship for parts.
Our scientists appear to have gone insane and killed one another or themselves. Not sending more scientists to their deaths was clearly the right decision.
We've sent another team of scientists. Hopefully we will discover what went wrong with the previous expedition.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Ancient Gizurean Ship Negative Outcome (Non Gizurean)
Ancient Gizurean Ship Positive Outcome (Non Gizurean)

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Gizurean Ship Negative Outcome (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description:
We have discovered what happened to the original team investigating the ancient ship. They were exposed to a psychic plague. We were unable to contain the infected, who felt an irrepressible urge to return to our homeworld. We were unable to stop them.
There is now an outbreak on the homeworld, and the disease threatens to spread rapidly throughout our populations. We must take steps as soon as possible to find a cure.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Gizurean Ship Positive Outcome (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description:
Our researchers found the previous team dead, having murdered one another in an orgy of unhinged violence. We cannot determine what caused them to go insane.
However, by studying the ship, we have learned a great deal about ancient Gizurean technology.
Our scientists have discovered a cure for the psychic plague. We have learned some things about medicine and ancient Gizurean technology in the process.

On this world we've discovered the remains of an ancient Gizurean colony. Though once heavily populated, it was likely destroyed in the Cataclysm.
Perhaps we should find out more, though it may be better not to know. We could simply dismantle the remains of the colony for resources, which are often more useful than knowledge.

There might have been some interesting information to be discovered in the ruins. We will never know.
And we don't care because we have received much of value from dismantling everything we could find. These resources can be used to fuel our growth. The past cannot help us grow stronger.

On the surface we've discovered a remarkably well-preserved archive. Unfortunately, in order to access it, a living Gizurean, preferably a scientist, will have to interface with a psychic device. The odds of this scientist surviving are approximately zero.
We could simply abandon the entire effort and hope to learn something simply by making a superficial examination of the archive, but it may be worth giving up a scientist in order to learn more.
Our scientists have looked over the archives. They gave it a good inspection and walked around the area. They are now much smarter as a result. They are very good scientists.

The scientist's death was unforgettable, but mostly in the sense of it being disgusting. The scientist entered this ancient archive and, after using various invasive mechanisms to interface with it, received a burst of information. The scientist's screaming, as well as the blood that poured from his mouth and eyes, gave the impression of the process being painful. He survived long enough to write down, in a frenzied burst, all he had learned. Then he expired, leaving a significant legacy of knowledge. Also a mess.

All his pain and suffering was a small price for the rest of us to pay. We have discovered a great deal of information about lost technology, and we have discovered a map with an important location identified.

On this world we've discovered the remains of an ancient colony, once heavily populated. It was likely destroyed in the Cataclysm.
Perhaps we should find out more, though we could simply dismantle the remains of the colony for resources.
We have received much of value from dismantling the remains of the ancient colony.

This colony once belonged to the ancient Gizureans. On the surface, we found a well preserved archive, but accessing it appears to require a species specific psychic link. We do not believe there is a way for us to gain access.
Nevertheless, we have discovered much about ancient Gizurean system design, which we will be able to apply to our own research.

We are receiving a message from the surface of Paxon.
"Gizureans! We know you. This world used to be yours, back before the Cataclysm. Now it is ours. You will be happy to hear that we are enjoying it! Over the centuries we have discovered some interesting ancient Gizurean artefacts. Maybe youd like them back. That is easily enough arranged. All you need to do is sign a Free Trade agreement. Also, you can pay us 100,000 CR. We have thought about it carefully and believe this is fair."
Do we give into the demands of these aliens? It would be good to get our hands on their ancient knowledge. But it would also be good to pry the knowledge from their dead hands. So much to consider.
These vile aliens will regret trying to extort us, withholding what rightly belongs to us. We shall have to return to this place and pry our property from their corpses.
You refused our offer

We have found some remarkable ruins on the surface of Paxon. It seems this was the home of the secondary palace of the ancient Gizurean queen. During the Shakturi War, she and her court fled here after the fall of the Gizurean homeworld. This was where the ancient Gizureans made their last stand against the Shakturi, with whom they were once allied, but who later proved to be treacherous. It was here that Gizurean civilization fell when some terrible fate afflicted the queen.
The Gizureans initially allied with the Shakturi. Perhaps by choice, though possibly they fell under the power of the Shakturis psychic control. Something happened to cause a break. It is possible the queen discovered that the Shakturi intended to destroy the Gizureans in the end, along with all life in the galaxy.
We have uncovered an ancient artefact, the Tactical Balance Datacore. This is a compendium of observations and strategies compiled during the final days of the Shakturi war and suggested new strategies and tactics that could be deployed against powerful enemies. There is no one more powerful than the Gizureans, but we can be even more spectacularly dangerous.
We have also discovered information pointing us toward the location of an ancient Gizurean shipyard, which we should explore.

We have found some ruins on the surface of Paxon. It seems this was the home of the secondary palace of the ancient Gizurean queen. During the Shakturi War, she and her court fled here after the fall of the Gizurean homeworld. This was where the ancient Gizureans made their last stand against the Shakturi, with whom they were previously allied.
We have uncovered an ancient artefact, the Tactical Balance Datacore. This is a compendium of observations and strategies compiled during the final days of the Shakturi war and suggested new strategies and tactics that could be deployed against powerful enemies.
We have also discovered information pointing us toward the location of an ancient Gizurean shipyard.

We believe that in the time before the Cataclysm, this was a Gizurean shipyard, where our clever engineers stole the best ideas from inferior aliens. Now it has been taken over by the creatures called the Hive.

The creatures of the Hive have created remarkable ships, cleverly adding to, and building upon, ships created by other species. It is impressive, and yet disturbing. Even being near these creatures or their creations is difficult. We hear voices whispering. Their proximity threatens to drive any Gizurean insane.
Their resemblance to our species is uncanny. Worth exploring. Perhaps their origins and ours is linked in some way.
If we could learn to be connected as they are to one another, we could grow even faster and stronger.

Among their cold corpses we have discovered a marvelous Artefact, the Gizurean Shipyard Schematic. This relic of the past will be housed at our homeworld, where we can study the shipbuilding and maintenance techniques deployed by our clever ancestors. We can use these ourselves, making us even smarter than they were since we still exist, and they do not.
We have also found a map which marks what we believe to be the Gizurean homeworld. Perhaps there is something of use to be found among our dead ancestors.
{1} is inhabited by the creatures called the Hive. We should proceed with great caution.

Among the ruins we have discovered an artifact, the Gizurean Shipyard Schematic, which details many of the shipbuilding and maintenance techniques deployed by the ancient Gizureans. We have moved it to our homeworld where it will aid our own shipbuilding efforts.
We have also found a map which marks what we believe to be the ancient Gizurean homeworld.

This is where we believe our people come from, the ancient homeworld of the Gizureans. It would be fascinating to see what we could plunder from the corpses of our forebears, but the system is overrun with the insane creatures called the Hive.

The Hive are attempting to communicate with us.
"Gizurean things. Old. Older version. Forgotten. Replaced. Lost cousins. Absorption! You will be destroyed and welcome. We will consume. Consume. Terrible, amusing death. Perhaps avoided if you speak with your minds."

Being near the Hive is terrible. There are images. Sounds. Voices. Pain. Terror. They will bring madness. These creatures seem familiar, and yet nothing could be more alien. We must eradicate them in order to preserve ourselves.

We do not understand what the Hive mean when they tell us to speak with our minds. If we want to explore our ancient homeworld, we'll have to take it from its current occupants. We must eliminate them.

We did not understand what these creatures meant when they required us to speak with our minds, but Sawa Echigo, the scientist we revived from cryosleep, says it is possible to form a psychic link with the Hive. Sawa Echigo has volunteered to attempt to make contact. He believes he can use the psychic link, which he say was common to all ancient Gizureans, to damage the Hive fleet. He will not survive the process. Should we accept or reject his offer?
Sawa Echigo is irritating, but he does good work. We will not let him sacrifice himself. If we want to explore our ancient homeworld, we'll have to take it from its current occupants.

Sawa Echigo, after resigning himself to his fate, simply found a place to sit quietly and, in his own words, "opened his mind" to the Hive.
It was terrible to behold. He screamed and writhed. Blood gushed from his mouth and nostrils. Then he fell dead. No one will miss him, but even so. This was commendable behavior. Particularly since moments later, the main hive carrier orbiting Dirann began to explode.
Sawa Echigo gave his life to help eliminate some of our enemies. We will have to finish the conquest on our own.

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Building World (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description: On Dyokara we have discovered a functional Advanced Shipyard. This will help us to build more ships and expand even more rapidly. Our greatness will know no bounds.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Building World (Non Gizurean)

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Hive Research World (Gizurean)

GeneratedItemEventNames.string: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Hive Research World (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description:
On Omaja, we have discovered the ruins of an ancient Gizurean facility.
After the destruction of the Shakturi wiped out most of Gizurean civilization, several survivors set out to try to restore their connection to the Hive mind. These were Gizureans like us, who survived because of their weaker psychic link.
They believed they could restore that link, and dedicated themselves to undertaking a massive research project.
The facility was destroyed by the Hive before our ancestors could complete their work, but, knowing that such destruction was likely, the Gizureans preserved their work in a data crystal. If we choose, we can dedicate ourselves to understanding this research, and thereby restore some portion of the Gizurean hive mind.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Hive Research World (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description:
We have completed our research that will allow us to retore our ancient hive mind. We can become as great as our ancestor once were. Even greater!
We are on the brink of a new era. Gizureans will never be the same again.
This appears to be the homeworld of the ancient Gizureans. It would be worth our while to explore it, but the world is overrun with the insane creatures called the Hive.

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Building World (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description: On Dyokara we have discovered a functional Advanced Shipyard. This will help us to build more ships and expand even more rapidly. Our greatness will know no bounds.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Building World Gizurean)

GameEvent.Name: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Hive Research World (Non Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description: On Omaja, we have discovered the ruins of an ancient Gizurean facility, dedicated to the study of how hive minds function.

GameEventAction.GeneratedItemName: Ancient Gizurean Homeworld Hive Research World (Gizurean)

GameEventAction.Description:
Now that we have destroyed the Hive presence infesting our ancient homeworld, we have been able to explore our place of origin.
We are shocked to learn that the Hive are, indeed, the lost cousins of the modern Gizureans. When the Shakturi first invaded this galaxy, they made common cause with other hive mind species, among which were the Gizureans. They began by claiming kinship with us, but they only wished to dominate. By the time the ancient Gizureans realized the danger, it was too late.

The Gizureans of the time were psychically linked to their queen and one another, something we modern Gizureans cannot fully understand. It proved to be a devastating blow to all Gizureans when the queen lost her sense of self to the psychic powers of the Shakturi. Once under their control, she existed only in a dreamlike state, barely alive but not quite dead.
When the Shakturi were destroyed in the Cataclysm, the Gizurean queen was finally freed, though freedom came far too late. Her mind was broken. Even so, our people were linked to her, and her death released psychic devastation felt by all of the hive mind. Some died. Some fell into a vegetative state. And some went insane, though this word does their state little justice. It was a kind of insanity no one had ever imagined, a complete warping of senses and perception. They became twisted, alien things driven by impulses no sane Gizurean can ever understand.
Those broken, distorted creatures are we now call the Hive.

There was a wide range of psychic abilities among the Gizurean population of the time. The only ones who both survived and escaped madness were those with very limited psychic capacity. These were our ancestors. Now we understand why we feel a constant sense of loss, a haunting sensation that we should be more than we are.
We must now accept that we are indeed diminished, but this knowledge also gives us a reason to push ever outward, to become more, to achieve all our ancestors did, and then more. We can become the new standard of greatness.

Our problems with the Hive will not disappear. Fortunately, we are now in a far better position to defeat them. Examining the ruins on the surface have given our researchers many insights.
On the planet surface we have discovered numerous remnants of Hive ships. Among them we found an analysis of these ships created by the ancient Gizureans. It is called the Hive Fleet Compendium, and it focuses on Hive techniques for rapidly boarding enemy vessels. By understanding the Hive better, we can become more powerful than they are. They should beware of us. Eventually.

Now that we have destroyed the Hive presence, we have been able to explore this world.
We have learned that when the Shakturi first invaded this galaxy, they made common cause with other hive mind species, among which were the Gizureans. They were able to use their psychic powers to bring other hive minds under their control. When the Shakturi were defeated, they broke their connection to the Gizurean queen, which caused many Gizureans to go mad.

On the planet surface we have discovered numerous remnants of Hive ships. Among them we found an analysis of these ships created by the ancient Gizureans. It is called the Hive Fleet Compendium, and it focuses on Hive techniques for rapidly boarding enemy vessels. There is much to learn from this.
